subject: statistics
title: CI for Mean with Known Variance
contentHtml:
In statistics, we often want to estimate a population mean based on a sample of data. When the population variance is known, we can use Z-intervals to construct a confidence interval (CI) for the true mean.

A Z-interval is a type of interval estimation that uses the standard normal distribution (Z-distribution) to calculate the margin of error. This approach is particularly useful when the sample size is large and the population variance is known.
name: Z-interval formula" },
intuition: The key insight here is that when we know the population variance, we can use the standard normal distribution to calculate the margin of error. This allows us to construct a CI for the true mean with a specific level of confidence.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, Z-intervals are used in hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for model performance metrics.
commonMistakes: Failing to account for the known population variance when constructing the CI

title: Confidence Intervals for Mean with Known Variance
contentHtml:
We're going to explore confidence intervals (CIs) for the mean of a population when we know the variance. This is a fundamental concept in statistical inference, and it has numerous applications in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

In particular, we'll focus on Z-intervals, which are widely used in practice due to their simplicity and accuracy.

intuition: The key insight is that the CI for the mean is a range of values within which we're confident (1 - α) that the true population mean lies. The Z-score plays a crucial role in determining this interval.

subject: statistics
title: Confidence Intervals for Mean with Known Variance
contentHtml:
In statistics, we often want to estimate a population mean based on a sample of data. When the variance is known, we can construct a confidence interval (CI) using the Z-interval method.

The CI provides a range of values within which the true population mean is likely to lie. The width of the interval represents our uncertainty in the estimation process.
intuition: Think of the CI as a 'window' around our sample mean. The width of this window depends on the known variance and the confidence level we choose.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, CIs are used to quantify the uncertainty in model predictions.
commonMistakes: Don't forget to account for the known variance when constructing the CI.
